entry.title: Quick test: Navigate using just your keyboard
entry.content:
One quick way that you can check your accessibility is to navigate through the site using nothing but your keyboard.

  1. Un-plug/turn off your mouse.
  2. Use the Tab key browse.
  3. Use Enter to select elements.
  4. Some menus and form elements may require ↑ ↓ ← → arrow keys.

This is by no means a complete accessibility check, but it can quickly help you find major accessibility problems.

Estimated Time: 5 seconds

entry.title: MYTH: Accessibility is "blind people"
entry.content:
Accessibility (A11Y) is often viewed often viewed as making your site work on a screen readers. In reality, web accessibility is a subset of UX focused on making your websites usable by the widest range of people possible, including those who have disabilities.

4 Categories of Accessibilitiy

In Ian Hamilton’s .net magazine article, A11Y is broken down into 4 key categories.

  Description Associated Conditions
Visual This can be non-sighted users, users with low-vision, users with obstructed vision, or even simply your aging parents.
  • Myopia
  • Colour blindness
  • Glaucoma
  • Albinism
Auditory The web is a visual medium, but captions and fallbacks for sound-necessary media need to be considered for hearing impaired users.
  • Presbycusis
  • Acoustic trauma
  • Auditory processing disorder
  • Otosclerosis
Motor People with motor impairments typically use a wide arrange of AT.
  • RSI
  • Cerebral palsy
  • Parkinson's
  • Muscular dystrophy
Cognitive Relates to the ease processing of information.
  • Downâ€™s syndrome
  • Autism
  • Global developmental delay
  • Dyslexia

Each of these areas of accessibility will be discussed further in-detail, specifically regarding web accessibility.

entry.content: WAI-ARIA is the HTML5 spec designed to increase the accessibility of web pages, dynamic content, and user interfaces developed with HTML5 and modern Javascript.

entry.title: How-to: Hide Content
entry.content:
Developers commonly use display: none to hide content on the page. Unfortunately, this simple and common action is a bit problematic.

Some screen readers will still read display: none content and some won’t1. There are also situations where you want to hide elements (i.e., a form label), but you still want it to be read by a screen reader. Here are CSS classes that you should include in every project and use responsibly.

/* http://webaim.org/techniques/css/invisiblecontent/ */
.screen-reader-text {
    position:absolute;
    left:-10000px;
    top:auto;
    width:1px;
    height:1px;
    overflow:hidden;
}

/* http://www.456bereastreet.com/archive/200711/screen_readers_sometimes_ignore_displaynone/ */
.hidden {
    display:none;
    visibility:hidden;
}
